user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_has_token_caseless_:
```c
bool
MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ (const char *str,
                             const char *const token,
                             size_t token_len)
{
  if (0 == token_len)
    return false;

  while (0 != *str)
  {
    size_t i;
    /* Skip all whitespaces and empty tokens. */
    while (' ' == *str || '\t' == *str || ',' == *str)
      str++;

    /* Check for token match. */
    i = 0;
    while (1)
    {
      const char sc = *(str++);
      const char tc = token[i++];

      if (0 == sc)
        return false;
      if (! charsequalcaseless (sc, tc))
        break;
      if (i >= token_len)
      {
        /* Check whether substring match token fully or
         * has additional unmatched chars at tail. */
        while (' ' == *str || '\t' == *str)
          str++;
        /* End of (sub)string? */
        if ((0 == *str) || (',' == *str) )
          return true;
        /* Unmatched chars at end of substring. */
        break;
      }
    }
    /* Find next substring. */
    while (0 != *str && ',' != *str)
      str++;
  }
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_str_has_token_caseless_:
_MHD_static_inline bool
charsequalcaseless (const char c1, const char c2)
{
  return ( (c1 == c2) ||
           (isasciiupper (c1) ?
            ((c1 - 'A' + 'a') == c2) :
            ((c1 == (c2 - 'A' + 'a')) && isasciiupper (c2))) );
}
...
_MHD_static_inline bool
isasciiupper (char c)
{
  return (c >= 'A') && (c <= 'Z');
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
const char sc = *(str++);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The expression '*(str++)' applies the post-increment operator to the parameter 'str', modifying the pointer value itself. Rule 17.8 forbids modifying a function parameter (the pointer itself), even though the object pointed to may be modified. This use therefore violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. Suggested fix: copy the parameter to a local pointer (e.g. 'const char *p = str;') and increment 'p' instead, or use an index variable.
